channel.title: The Beatles Anthology Revisited
channel.itunes:author: The Beatles
channel.description: The Beatles Anthology Revisited is an 18-part, 28-hour podcast telling the band's story entirely in their own words, those who were there, and various TV and radio newsreels of the time. There are also Beatles tunes, of course, most released, some buried treasures. It's both exhilarating and exhausting, but, if you take a break every four or five hours, your life will finally have meaning. Bottom line, it's everything you ever wanted to know about The Beatles, and a little bit more...

item.title: Episode 1: Flaming Pie (1940-1960)
item.description: This is Episode 1 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which four lads are born and raised in Liverpool, start a band, and go to and from Hamburg. A story to end all stories starts here. This version is the updated 2016 "Complete Edition," with improved audio snippets, new information, and extensive reediting to better tell this story of stories.

item.title: Episode 2: The Cavern (1960-1962)
item.description: This is Episode 2 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which our lads become a local Liverpool sensation, gaining the attention of one Mr. Epstein...

item.title: Episode 3: One Long Twelve-Hour Session (January - October 1963)
item.description: This is Episode 3 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads record their first album and enjoy the first inklings of stardom, unaware of what's to come...

item.title: Episode 4: Beatlemania (October 1963 - February 1964)
item.description: This is Episode 4 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which our lads become a national sensation, get the Queen to rattle her jewelry, and play to 73 million Americans. There's no going back now.

item.title: Episode 5: Three Ring Circus (February - December 1964)
item.description: This is Episode 5 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads make a movie, John writes a book, Ringo gets replaced (for a week), and Bob Dylan gets them high. So many beginnings (and endings) in this episode...

item.title: Episode 6: The Next Film (January - August 1965)
item.description: This is Episode 6 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads make another movie, get stoned (John and George drop acid for the first time), and write some of their best work. And the madness gets madder...

item.title: Episode 7: The Biggest Crowd (August - December 1965)
item.description: This is Episode 7 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads perform at Shea Stadium to the largest concert crowd ever (at the time), drop more acid, and meet Elvis. Oh, and they make Rubber Soul too.

item.title: Episode 8: Recording (January - June 1966)
item.description: This is Episode 8 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads record Revolver and make a cool album cover in what would be their one and only controversy in America...

item.title: Episode 9: Touring (June - December 1966)
item.description: This is Episode 9 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which America and the Philippines actually try to kill the lads. Later, George gets Indian, John makes another movie, Ringo spots him, and Paul dies. Strangely, no one notices. Yoko enters stage left, driving the final nail in John and Cynthia's marriage.

item.title: Episode 10: Fictitious Band (January - August 1967)
item.description: This is Episode 10 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads destroy Brian Wilson's hopes and dreams with Sgt. Pepper, which in turn becomes the hit album to end all hit albums. The Summer of Love, etc.

item.title: Episode 11: Circle (August 1967 - February 1968)
item.description: This is Episode 11 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which Brian Epstein suddenly dies, the lads meet the Maharishi, and Paul writes the band's next film by drawing a circle. Results are as expected...

item.title: Episode 12: India (February - July 1968)
item.description: This is Episode 12 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads go to India with the Maharishi, get back, and start making the White Album. Tensions get high, but they are still able to release "Hey Jude / Revolution," their best-selling single of their career. Things start coming down fast...

item.title: Episode 13: No Cover (July - December 1968)
item.description: This is Episode 13 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the White Album gets finished and released, despite even more tension and Ringo's temporary departure! The lads do their own things for a bit, and John and Yoko get busted (not a spoiler, I promise you...)

item.title: Episode 14: The Low of All Time (January 1969)
item.description: This is Episode 14 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads try to Get Back to their roots. It fails miserably.

item.title: Episode 15: Abbey Road (February - September 1969)
item.description: This is Episode 15 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which John and George make more solo stuff, John and Yoko get married and make a song out of it, and the lads record Abbey Road with surprisingly little tension, because even they knew this was their last hurrah.

item.title: Episode 16: Collapsed (September 1969 - April 1970)
item.description: This is Episode 16 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which people finally find about Paul's death; the lads are bemused. Phil Spector takes over with the Get Back project and makes Let it Be, to the band's relief (despite Paul's added frustration over its sound). John asks for a divorce, and like that, it's over. The Beatles break up. But the story doesn't end here...

item.title: Episode 17: Ended Up (1970-1980)
item.description: This is Episode 17 of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the lads are lads no more. Solo stuff, petty rumours, private reunions, and a life's end at decade's dawn.

item.title: Episode 18: Together Again (1981-2016)
item.description: This is the final episode of The Beatles Anthology Revisited, in which the three lads recover from John's death, do more great solo stuff, and reunite to make one great retrospective of their old band. George eventually leaves the material world, leaving Paul and Ringo to maintain the legacy of the band that changed everything.
